Fig. 1 Experimental XRD patterns for reduced Ni_Alum catalyst. Fig. 2 HRTEM images of reduced Ni_Alum catalyst. (a,b) sample morphology; (c) HAADF-STEM image; (d) corresponding EDX mapping. Fig. 3 Scheme of the transformations of benzofuran and intermediates over Ni_Alum catalyst (ki are the quasi-first order rate constants). BFN: 2,3-benzofuran; DBFN: 2,3-dihydrobenzofuran; OBFN: octahydrobenzofuran; 2-EPEL: 2-ethylphenol; 2-MPEL: 2-methylphenol; 2-ECHL: 2-ethylcyclohexanol; 2-ECHON: 2-ethylcyclohexanone; 2-MCHL: 2-methylcyclohexanol; 2-MCHON: 2-methylcyclohexanone; ECHN: ethylcyclohexane; MCHN: methylcyclohexane. Fig. 5 Experimental XRD patterns for Ni_Alum catalyst after transfer hydrogenation in 2-PrOH at different temperatures. (a) 82 °C; (b) 150 °C; (c) 250 °C; (d) 300 °C. Fig. 6 Experimental XRD patterns for Ni_Alum catalyst after transfer hydrogenation at 250 °С in different media. (a) MeOH; (b) EtOH; (c) 1-PrOH; (d) mixture 2-PrOH-EtOH. Fig. 7 HRTEM images of Ni_Alum_Me_250 catalyst. (a) sample morphology; (b) crystal structure of Ni3C and Ni0 crystallites; (c) HAADF-STEM image of catalyst; (d) corresponding EDX mapping. Fig. 8 HRTEM images of Ni_Alum_1-Pr_250 catalyst: (a) sample morphology; (b) crystal structure of Ni3C and Ni1–x C x crystallites; (c) EDX mapping image of the catalyst; (d) particles of different carbides on the Al2O3 surface. Fig. 9 An assumed scheme of Ni3C phase formation under transfer hydrogenation conditions in primary alcohols. Fig. 10 Experimental XRD patterns for Ni_Alum catalyst after transfer hydrogenation in EtOH at different temperatures. (a) 150 °C; (b) 200 °C; (c) 250 °C. Fig. 11 In situ FMR study of the Ni_Alum catalyst evolution in the presence of EtOH. (a) At 250 °C (the pressure during the experiment was in the range of 85–90 atmospheres): (i) 0 min, (ii) 20 min, (iii) 35 min, (iv) 60 min, (v) 90 min, (vi) 110 min and the result of the spectra simulation using the Lorentzian line shape. (b) The integral intensity of the spectrum components as a function on time. (c) The width of the spectra components as a function on time. Available online 20 March 2024 Article Primary alcohols as killers of Ni-based catalysts in transfer hydrogenation Nikolay Nesterov * Alexey Philippov * Vera Pakharukova Evgeny Gerasimov Stanislav Yakushkin Oleg Martyanov Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis SB RAS, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia * Corresponding author The effect of different types of alcohols used as hydrogen donors on the activity of a metal Ni-based catalyst in the hydrogenation of benzofuran as a model substrate under transfer hydrogenation conditions has been studied. The hydrogenation process of benzofuran using 2-PrOH as a hydrogen donor leads sequentially to dearomatization and then to deoxygenation of the substrates. At the same time, the use of primary alcohols such as MeOH, EtOH and 1-PrOH as hydrogen donors leads to irreversible deactivation of the Ni-containing catalyst. A clear mechanism of deactivation of Ni-based metal catalysts by primary alcohols has been established. The interaction of the catalyst with primary alcohols at a temperature of 250 °C leads to the formation of an inactive Ni3C carbide phase, as well as sintering and segregation of metal particles on the surface of the alumina support. Graphical Abstract Ni-containing catalysts show activity and stability in reducing transformations using secondary alcohols as hydrogen donors. Primary alcohols lead to deactivation of the catalysts due to the formation of an inactive Ni3C carbide phase and sintering of the metallic Ni phase. Keywords Benzofuran Transfer hydrogenation Supercritical coprecipitation Ni-catalysts Alcohols 1 Introduction Nowadays, alcohols are considered as one of the most promising hydrogen donors, whose activity has been demonstrated many times [1–3]. In contrast to molecular hydrogen, alcohols are easy to handle and safe to transport. Another important advantage of alcohols is that they can be easily produced from inedible plant biomass [4,5], whereas H2 production requires fossil or fresh water and electricity [6,7]. It is important to note that the use of alcohols as Н-donors, called transfer hydrogenation (TH), can be more effective compared to conventional hydrogenation in terms of conversion and yield [8–10]. This shows that TH is an independent and promising method of hydrogenation, for example, this approach shows excellent results in biomass conversions [1,11–13]. Biomass conversion is a bulk process and therefore heterogeneously catalyzed transformations are of great interest. Among many catalytic systems, metal-nickel catalysts show excellent results combining high catalytic activity and low price [1]. There are many studies describing the effectiveness of nickel-based catalysts in TH of 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural and its derivatives, where both carbonyl [14,15] and aromatic groups [16,17] can be saturated. Nickel-based catalysts also show high activity in TH of phenolic compounds [18–20], which are used as model products of lignin conversion. In our recent studies [21,22], the conversion of biomass-like phenolic molecules in EtOH and 2-PrOH was analyzed in detail. Highly loaded nickel catalysts prepared by the promising method based on precipitation in supercritical CO2 were used. This synthesis technique, due to the high degree of supersaturation [23], allows the synthesis of mixed systems with a high degree of homogeneity and defects [24,25], as well as highly dispersed deposited metal systems [26,27]. Thus, the mixed oxide SmCoO3 obtained in a supercritical CO2 leads to a metallic Co-containing catalyst that is highly active in the dry reforming of methane [28] and in the partial oxidation of methane [29]. Thus, the precipitation in supercritical CO2 allows to obtain the highly dispersed nickel catalysts that can be used both in traditional hydrogenation processes [30] and in TH [31]. It is interesting to note that the vast majority of studies describe excellent donor activity of secondary alcohols in the presence of nickel-based catalysts, while primary alcohols show limited or even no activity [15,32–34]. For example, Zhang et al. [33] compared the effect of lower aliphatic alcohols in the TH of fatty acid esters over Raney nickel. MeOH and EtOH were shown to have lower donor activity than 2-PrOH, 2-BuOH and 2-PnOH. The authors explain the observed effect by the high adsorption capacity of aldehydes formed during the dehydrogenation of alcohols. This leads to deactivation of the catalyst and reduces its performance in TH. In our recent work, we have found that the use of aldehydes together with Raney nickel facilitates carbon chain shortening [35,36], which can lead to CO formation; this gas is known for its poisoning activity for nickel-based catalysts. Thus, the formation of aldehydes from primary alcohols is considered to be a key factor in the deactivation of metal-nickel catalysts. At the same time, Wang et al. [32] mentioned the slow dehydrogenation of primary alcohols from alkoxy structures, resulting in the formation of aldehydes. All of the above studies on deactivation of nickel catalysts in primary alcohols did not find significant changes in catalyst composition and structure during TH. This is not surprising as these works dealt with low temperatures, not higher than 150 °C, due to the low temperature stability of bulk Ni-based catalysts, in particular the Raney nickel catalyst. However, processes such as the hydrotreating of petroleum products [37] or the deoxygenation of biofuels [38] require much harder conditions but to date, we have not found any literature data on high temperature TH in the medium of primary alcohols and the effect of such processes on the structure of heterogeneous catalysts. At the same time, in order to determine the reasons for the low donor activity of primary alcohols compared to secondary alcohols in TH, it is necessary to study the action of the catalysts and their possible structural changes at elevated temperatures. Increasing of the process temperature may also facilitate desorption of aldehydes from the active surface and trigger a catalytic reaction. In order to clearly solve the problem concerning the action of primary alcohols, we chose a stable and highly loaded Ni-containing catalyst obtained by precipitation in supercritical CO2 [22], using alumina as a stabilizing matrix. This allowed us to follow the changes in Ni-based catalysts that cause low donor activity of primary alcohols compared to secondary alcohols in TH, using different C1–C3 alcohols as H-donors in catalytic and catalyst-free transformations of benzofuran (here and below 2,3-benzofuran). Thus, this study demonstrates for the effect of primary and secondary alcohols on the structure changes and catalytic performance of the high-loaded Ni catalysts in high-temperature transfer hydrogenation. For this purpose, the relationships between reaction conditions, the catalyst structure and kinetic parameters of benzofuran transformations were thoroughly analyzed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Methanol (MeOH, HPLC gradient grade), ethanol (EtOH, ≥ 99.9%, Sigma Aldrich), 2-propanol (2-PrOH, ≥ 99.8%, EKOS-1), 1-propanol (EKOS-1), 2,3-benzofuran (99%, Sigma Aldrich), dodecane (≥ 98%, Chemical Line), Ni(OAc)2·4H2O (99%, Sigma Aldrich), aluminum tri-(sec-butoxide) (97%, Acros Organic), acetylacetone (≥ 99%, Sigma Aldrich), CO2 (99.8%, Promgazservis). 2.2 Сatalyst preparation The catalyst preparation procedure involved two main steps: synthesis of Al2O3 sol and coprecipitation of the formed sol together with Ni(OAc)2·4H2O in supercritical CO2. To prepare the sol, 4 mL of acetylacetone was added to 38 mL of 2-propanol under constant stirring, and then 5 mL of aluminum tri-(sec-butoxide) was added to this solution. After the addition of aluminum tri-(sec-butoxide), a white precipitate was formed. Then 70 mL of methanol was added to the suspension. After stirring for 15 min, the precipitate dissolved and 2.82 mL of water was added to the resulting solution. The solution was stirred for 24 h. The Ni_Alum catalyst was synthesized by supercritical antisolvent (SAS) coprecipitation of Ni(OAc)2·4H2O and Al2O3 sol using a specially designed SAS-50 apparatus (Waters, USA). The experimental parameters were 80 g/min CO2 flow, 2 mL/min solution flow, 40 °C, 150 bar, nozzle diameter 0.1 mm. The concentration of nickel acetate was 35.7 mg/mL in Al2O3 sol (total volume 120 mL). After precipitation, the catalyst was calcined at 300 °C for 3 h at a ramp rate of 3 °C/min in static air to obtain the oxide phase. The Ni_Alum catalyst was reduced in a Н2 flow (30 mL/min) at 650 °C for 45 min with a ramp rate of 3 °C/min. The optimum reduction temperature of the catalyst was determined in Ref. [39]. The reduced Ni_Alum catalyst consists of 50 wt% metallic Ni by loading. The Ni_Sil catalyst was prepared by SAS coprecipitation with the same experimental parameters [39]. The Ni_Sil catalyst was reduced in a Н2 flow (30 mL/min) at 400 °C for 45 min with a ramp rate of 3 °C/min. The reduced Ni_Sil catalyst consists of 50 wt% metallic Ni and 50 wt% SiO2 by loading. The Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by deposition-precipitation method [15]. The Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was reduced in a Н2 flow (30 mL/min) at 550 °C for 45 min with a ramp rate of 3 °C/min. The reduced Ni/Al2O3 catalyst consists of 20 wt% metallic Ni by loading. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7093 Å) on a STOE STADI MP diffractometer (STOE, Germany) equipped with a one-dimensional silicon strip MYTHEN2 1K detector (Dectris AG, Switzerland). Measurements were performed in transmission geometry in a rotating holder. Prior to measurement, the instrument was calibrated against a NIST SRM 660c standard (LaB6). Measurements were performed by scanning in the angular range 1.5°–127° with a step of 0.015°. XRD phase analysis was performed using the ICDD PDF-2 database. Average crystallite sizes (D XRD) were estimated using the Scherrer equation. The morphology and microstructure of the samples were examined by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The images were obtained using a Themis Z electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific, The Netherlands) equipped with a Ceta 16 CCD sensor and a spherical aberration corrector, providing a maximum lattice resolution of 0.07 nm at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples for the HRTEM study were deposited on a perforated carbon film mounted on an aluminum grid by ultrasonic dispersion of the catalyst suspension in ethanol. Interplanar distances were calculated from Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) patterns using Velox software (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) and Digital Micrograph (Gatan, USA). In situ ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) studies were performed using a Bruker Elexsys500 ESR spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) equipped with a TE011 high-temperature cylindrical X-band cavity ER 4114HT with temperature control. For the study of hydrogen reduction, a sample was placed in a flow-through quartz reactor through which a flow of hydrogen was passed at a rate of 0.3 L/h. The temperature was controlled by an internal W-Re thermocouple. In the case of the high-pressure isopropanol experiments, the catalyst samples were placed in a sapphire capillary with an outer diameter of 4 mm and an inner diameter of 1.2 mm, which was connected to the high pressure pump HPD Bischoff (Germany) and a back pressure regulator connected to the 2-PrOH vessel. The temperature inside the high-pressure capillary was calculated during the preparatory experiment, which was carried out at normal pressure with an internal thermocouple. The scheme of the experimental setup can be found in [40]. The FMR spectrum simulation was performed using the Levenberg-Marquardt method with individual spectral components of Lorentzian line shape. The R2 values obtained were in the range of 0.99. 2.4 Batch experiments To activate the oxidized catalysts, the samples (0.41–0.42 g in the experiments at 82 and 150 °C or 0.11–0.12 g at 200, 250 and 300 °C) were reduced in a flow of H2 (30 L/h) for 45 min. The process was performed in a quartz tube at 650 °C. After reduction, the tube containing the sample was removed from the furnace and cooled to room temperature in a flow of H2. The tube was then purged with Ar and, avoiding contact with air, exchanged for a glass filled with 30 mL of alcohols using an H donor. Catalytic experiments were performed in the batch reactor (AISI 316L, 285 mL) at 150, 200, 250 and 300 °C and in a glass reactor at 82 °C. The reactor was purged with argon and then charged with the catalyst suspension and 30 mL of alcohol. A solution of benzofuran (0.92 g 7.80 mmol), 0.30 g dodecane (internal standard) and 80 mL of alcohol was then added. In the experiment with the EtOH-2-PrOH mixture, 55 mL of each alcohol was mixed and then the standard procedure was followed. The reactor was then purged with argon while stirring (MagneDrive® mechanical stirrer), sealed and heated to 82, 150, 200, 250 or 300 °C for 14, 20, 25, 32 or 38 min at 800 r/min with continuous stirring. The reaction mixture autoclave pressure data were within the range shown in Table 1 . Benzofuran was also used in catalyst-free transformations at 250 °C, which were carried out according to the above procedure without catalyst activation and addition. Catalyst reuse was performed according to the standard procedure described above. 2-PrOH was used as the sole H donor at 250 °C. After completion of the reaction (3 h), the reaction mixture was cooled to 50 °C, and then the reaction solution was carefully decanted using the glass syringe under an inert atmosphere. The spent catalyst was washed with 100 mL of 2-PrOH under stirring in the reactor and then used for the catalytic conversion of benzofuran. Sampling was performed immediately after the temperature in the reactor reached 250 °C and then after 20, 60 and 180 min. The following equations were used to calculate the conversion, yield and specific catalytic activity: (1) Conversion = C ( benzofuran ) in - C ( benzofuran ) fin C ( benzofuran ) in × 100 % (2) Yield = C ( product ) Σ C ( product ) × 100 % where C(benzofuran)in is the initial concentration of the heteroaromatic compound, C(benzofuran)fin is a concentration of the heteroaromatic compound at a certain time. 2.5 Product analysis The liquid products of chemical transformations were analyzed using a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 SE chromate mass spectrometer equipped with an autosampler. A GsBP-INOWAX (cross-linked polyethylene glycol) capillary chromatography column (length, 30 m; internal diameter, 0.32 mm; stationary phase thickness, 0.25 μm) was used. The temperature mode of the column conditioning was as follows: 55 °C for 3 min, programmed heating to 200 °C at a rate of 15 °C per minute and then to 250 °C at a rate of 25 °C per minute. The evaporator temperature was 270 °C, split 1:30; helium was used as carrier gas. The products were identified from the peak retention time and mass spectrum of the substance, which were compared with the corresponding data of the pure compounds or with data from the NIST and Wiley7 electronic mass spectral libraries. The conversion of anisole and yield of the products were evaluated using an internal standard method with dodecane as the internal standard. To determine the qualitative composition of the gases formed, the reactor was cooled to 40 °C as the pressure dropped to 0.4–2.0 MPa. A portion of the gas was then withdrawn from the reactor using a 150 mL syringe. Before analysis, the gas in the syringe was diluted 20 times with air. The chromatographic analysis was performed using a Chromos GC 1000 (Russia) equipped with a chromatography column (length 2 m; internal diameter 3 mm; stationary phase NaX zeolite) and a thermal conductivity detector. Ar was used as acarrier gas. The temperature mode of column conditioning was as follows: 30 °C for 3 min, programmed heating to 120 °C at a rate of 24 °C/min, then 1 min at 120 °C. 2.6 Calculations of kinetic data The rate constants describing the consumption of starting and intermediate compounds were calculated according to Eq. (3): (3) d C i d t = - k i × C i where Ci is a concentration of the starting or intermediate compound in the solution at a certain time, ki is a kinetic constant of the consumption of the starting or intermediate compound. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of freshly prepared catalyst In this study, the 50 wt% Ni_Alum catalyst was used. Firstly, this catalyst showed excellent results in TH of anisole [39] and secondly, the high content of active phase allows us to study in detail the structural changes that occur during TH. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the Ni_Alum catalyst obtained after reduction in an H2 stream at 650 °C. The most intense peaks belong to the crystalline phase of metallic nickel Ni0 (PDF no. 00-004-0850). The defined value of the crystal lattice parameter a = 3.527(1) Å is close to the standard value for the Ni0 phase (a = 3.524 Å, PDF no. 00-004-0850). This catalyst has a sufficiently high dispersion of Ni0 particles for a loading of 50 wt%, as the average size (D XRD) of the Ni0 crystallites is about 5.0 nm. In addition, the XRD pattern shows strongly broadened peaks characteristic of the highly dispersed γ-Al2O3 phase (PDF No. 00-029-0063) with a spinel-type structure. Fig. 2 shows TEM data and EDX mapping of the Ni_Alum catalyst immediately after reduction. The catalyst sample is composed of spherical agglomerates with dimensions of 100 nm or more (Figs. 2(a,b) ). These agglomerates consist of Ni0 and γ-Al2O3 crystallites, which are uniformly distributed throughout the volume of the agglomerates according to the EDX mapping data (Figs. 2(c,d)). Previous work [22,39] has shown that, despite the high content of metal phase (50 wt%), this composition of the catalyst allows one to obtain an optimal dispersion and accessibility of the active centers of the catalyst, however, the statistical analysis of the average particle size of nickel by TEM is not possible, because the boundaries between separated crystallites are not clearly visible. As shown by catalytic tests in a 2-PrOH medium, the catalyst has thermal stability up to sintering at 300 °C (Fig. 5 ). Based on the data obtained, we can conclude that the synthesized catalysts have a uniform distribution of nickel and a high dispersion, which is in good agreement with our previous results [39]. 3.2 Transfer hydrogenation of benzofuran The hydrogenation of furan structures is of interest as a model process for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of coal-derived liquids, oil shale, tar sands [41] and bio-oil [42]. It should be noted that the HDO of petroleum products always takes place under the industrial conditions of the hydrotreating process. The analysis of the benzofuran transformation products under TH conditions allowed us to establish the transformation scheme (Fig. 3 ), which fits the experimental data very well. Based on this scheme, kinetic modeling was carried out and chemical rate constants were calculated for all stages during TH under different conditions. The analysis of the composition of the reaction mixture indicates that in the first stage a partial hydrogenation of 2,3-benzofuran (BFN) to 2,3-dihydrobenzofuran (DBFN) takes place. Subsequently, we assume that there are three main conversion pathways. The first pathway leads to the complete hydrogenation of DBFN, resulting in the formation of octahydrobenzofuran (OBFN), and then the C–O bond cleavage is observed, leading to the 2-ethylcyclohexanol (2-ECHL) found in the mixture. The C–O bond cleavage is also typical of the second pathway, in which DBFN is first converted to 2-ethylphenol (2-EPEL), and then saturation of the aromatic ring and cleavage of the remaining C–O bond occur sequentially. This results in the formation of 2-ECHL or ethylcyclohexane (ECHN). In the third transformation pathway, the cleavage of the C–O bond in the DBFN molecule is accompanied by the loss of a carbon atom, resulting in the formation of 2-methylphenol (2-MPEL). Further stepwise hydrogenation of 2-MPEL leads first to 2-MCHL and after deoxygenation to methylcyclohexane (MCHN). In the case of the formation of two secondary alcohols, 2-ECHL and 2-MCHL, the ketones 2-ethylcyclohexanone (2-ECHON) and 2-methylcyclohexanone (2-MCHON) are also observed in the mixture. It can be assumed that they are formed as a result of reversible dehydrogenation of the corresponding alcohols. It should be noted that complete deoxygenation products such as ECHN and MCHN are observed only at 300 °C. The sequence of transformations observed for benzofuran, including ring opening and further saturation, is quite typical for Ni-based catalysts. For example, conventional hydrogenation of benzofuran over the reduced Ni-Mo/Al2O3 catalyst resulted in DBFN, 2-EPEL and ECHN [43]. In another study, similar catalysts showed activity in full saturation of benzofuran to OBFN [44]. The scheme of benzofuran transformations in conventional hydrogenation catalyzed by NiCu/SiO2 includes partial saturation of the initial substrate to DBFN, then cleavage of C–O bonds occurs resulting in ethylbenzene and ECHN [45]. It is interesting to note that in some cases shorter C6 and C7 products are observed. Carbon chain shortening under Ni-catalyzed TH conditions is typical for some types of molecules, even under relatively mild conditions. In particular, aldehydes and primary alcohols have been shown to lose carbon atoms [35,46], but no such examples have been found for benzofuran. At the same time, it has been shown for H2 hydrogenation in the presence of Ni-containing catalysts that the formation of toluene and/or methylcyclohexane also occurs with benzofuran HDO [47,48]. The authors of both studies suggest that the ethylcyclohexane molecule is exposed to C–C bond cleavage, but this seems unlikely for TH due to the relatively mild experimental conditions. Unfortunately, the mechanism of decarbonization under TH conditions is not fully understood, but it is clear that the presence of an oxygen atom in the molecule contributes to the appearance of chain shortening products. Table S1 shows the calculated rate constants according to the scheme of the benzofuran transformations (Fig. 3). All constants were calculated using the quasi-first order kinetic model. At 82 °C, only the transformations of BFN to DBFN (rate constant of formation k 1) and DBFN to 2-EPEL and 2-MPEL (k 4 and k 6, respectively) are observed. In boiling 2-PrOH (82 °C) no further dearomatization and deoxygenation are observed. At temperatures of 150 and 250 °C, the dehydrogenation rates of 2-EPEL and 2-MPEL are already noticeable, leading to the formation of the alcohols 2-ECHL and 2-MCHL (k 5 and k 7, respectively), as well as to the formation of a fully saturated product - OBFN, the precursor of which also appears to be DBFN (k 3). Since secondary alcohols are formed as a consequence of the saturation of the aromatic ring, they can be dehydrogenated like 2-PrOH, so that at a temperature of 250 °C the formation of 2-ECHON is observed, whose concentration is determined by the reversible transformations of k 8 and k 9. The deoxygenation products of ECHN and MCHN are observed only at a temperature of 300 °C (transformations of k 10 and k 13). It should be noted that there are no aromatic products in the mixture that do not contain oxygen atoms, which is probably characterized by a stronger adsorption of aromatic compounds on the surface of the catalyst and the deoxygenation only becomes noticeable when the aromatic rings are completely saturated. The conversion of BFN to DBF at 250 °C in a mixture of EtOH and 2-PrOH is much slower than even at 82 °C in a reaction using 2-propanol as the sole hydrogen donor (conversion k 1). However, it should be noted that the C–O bond cleavage (conversion of DBF to 2-EPEL and 2-MPEL) has a higher rate than at 82 °C (conversions of k 4 and k 6). At the same time, the presence of EtOH in the reaction mixture has a negative effect on the rate of dearomatization and deoxygenation, since no products corresponding to these processes were detected. To demonstrate the long-term stability of the catalyst in secondary alcohols, three reuse experiments were performed with benzofuran, 2-PrOH and the same Ni_Alum sample at 250 °C. Before the first run, the catalyst was reduced in H2 stream according to the standard procedure, then to avoid oxidation and catalyst loss, the sample was decanted and washed with fresh 2-PrOH inside the reactor. The kinetic curves obtained show good reproducibility in terms of conversion, selectivity (Fig. S2) and calculated rate constants (see Table S2). In addition, it has been shown by XRD (Fig. S3 and Table S3) that after three experiments the catalyst sample retains its initial structure and does not contain any additional phases. All these observations indicate a superior long-term stability of Ni catalysts in secondary alcohols compared to primary alcohols. Fig. 4 Percentage composition of the reaction mixtures as functions of time. (a) m(Ni_Alum) = 0.42 g, 82 °C, 2-PrOH; (b) m(Ni_Alum) = 0.42 g, 150 °C, 2-PrOH; (c) m(Ni_Alum) = 0.12 g, 250 °C, 2-PrOH; (d) m(Ni_Alum) = 0.12 g, 275 °C, 2-PrOH; (e) m(Ni_Alum) = 0.12 g, 250 °C, 2-PrOH + EtOH. The points are experimental data and the lines are data calculated from the quasi-first order kinetic model. There is no consensus in the literature on the reasons for the low activity of primary alcohols in hydrogen transfer processes, but competing sorption is often a common explanation [32–34]. Either the primary alcohol or the product of its dehydrogenation is adsorbed on metallic nickel and blocks the surface. It is worth noting that in these Raney nickel was used as the catalyst and the process temperature was not higher than 150 °C, since sintering of the catalyst occurs at higher temperatures [49]. Working with supported catalysts allows processes to be carried out at higher temperatures. It should also be noted that an increase in temperature can lead to desorption of various molecules from the catalyst surface, which can contribute to an increase in the donor activity of primary alcohols under TH conditions. At a temperature of 250 °C, experiments were carried out on the H2-free hydrogenation of benzofuran in primary alcohols: methanol, ethanol and 1-propanol. However, in all primary alcohols the benzofuran conversion did not exceed 5%. It should be noted that in the case of both 2-propanol and primary alcohols, gaseous hydrogen is present in the mixture (Fig. S1) and must be adsorbed on the catalyst for hydrogenation to occur. In the case of 2-PrOH, water, propylene, and acetone were detected in the reaction mixtures, but these products do not appear to interfere with the catalytic transformations. When primary alcohols are used, no hydrogenation takes place. To find out the reasons for this, we decided to perform a detailed analysis of the catalysts after a series of catalytic experiments and in situ studies of the catalysts. 3.3 Catalyst characterization after transfer hydrogenation of benzofuran Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns for the Ni_Alum catalyst after transfer hydrogenation in 2-PrOH at different temperatures. The transfer hydrogenation process in a 2-PrOH medium does not lead to significant phase changes in the composition of the catalysts compared to the Ni_Alum catalyst after reduction (Table 2 ). For example, peaks of metallic Ni0 phase are observed in all XRD patterns (PDF no. 00-004-0850), the average sizes of Ni0 crystallites are in the range of 5.0–6.0 nm, and the lattice parameters are in the range of 3.525–3.527 Å, which is close to the standard value of 3.524 Å. XRD patterns of the Ni_Alum catalyst after transfer hydrogenation in a medium of primary alcohols as well as in an EtOH-2-PrOH mixture at 250 °C are shown in Fig. 6 . Table 3 presents data on the phase composition and structural characteristics of the crystalline phases found in the catalyst after the catalytic processes. In the catalyst, a new Ni3С phase with an average crystallite size of 18.5 nm is formed after MeOH, and the crystallite sizes of the metallic Ni0 phase are increased from 5.0 to 19.0 nm. After interaction with EtOH, Ni3C and Ni0 phases with average D XRD sizes of 29.5 and 12.0 nm, respectively, are detected in the catalyst. A highly dispersed (D XRD = 4 nm) phase is also observed in the catalyst sample after EtOH, which is isostructural to a metallic Ni0 phase. This phase is characterized by a significantly larger lattice parameter a = 3.628 Å compared to metallic Ni0. This phase is probably a metastable Ni1–x C x substitutional solid solution [50]. When 1-PrOH is used, Ni0 and Ni1–x C x phases with sizes of 16.5 and 5.0 nm are observed in the catalyst sample, as well as traces of the Ni3C phase. After the interaction of the catalyst with the EtOH-2-PrOH mixture, the Ni0 and Ni1–x C x phases with sizes of 7.0 and 3.5 nm, respectively, are observed in the XRD pattern. Transmission electron microscopy data confirm the phase composition observed by XRD. For the catalyst, rounded agglomerates with dimensions of 100–400 nm and lamellar agglomerates of a dendrite-like type with dimensions of 20-200 nm are observed after MeOH (see Fig. 7(a) ). The study of the phase composition showed that the rounded particles are composed of aluminum oxide and metallic nickel. The lamellar agglomerates consist of several components, such as metallic nickel, nickel carbide and nickel oxide, which are located on the surface of the agglomerates. The nickel carbide of this modification is characterized by a spacing of 3.38 Å, which is the interplanar spacing for planes (012). In Fig. 7(b) this carbide is marked with a white circle. The HAADF STEM experiments (Fig. 7(c)) show that the amount of nickel in the structure of the rounded particles has significantly decreased as the signal is not as intense. EDX mapping of this area (Fig. 7(d)) also shows a reduction of Ni to 10 at% relative to alumina. In addition, the mapping clearly shows that some of the nickel is enriched with carbon, consistent with the formation of nickel carbide. In the catalyst, after reaction in propanol, metallic and carbide Ni particles are released from the surface of the initial rounded agglomerates. The size of these particles varies from 5 to 30 nm. Fibrous nickel oxide particles are also observed on the surface (Fig. 8(a) ). The formation of these oxide particles probably occurred after the sample was transported through the air. The study of the phase composition showed that two types of carbide particles can be distinguished. First, there are Ni3C particles with sizes of 5–10 nm, similar to those observed in the sample after treatment in methanol. In addition, particles with a structure similar to metallic nickel oxide but containing carbon in the composition are observed. These particles are characterized by increased interplanar spacings, e.g. if the spacing (111) for Ni is 2.03 Å, it increases to 2.1 Å for these types of particles (Fig. 8(b)). Mapping showed that the surface of the rounded particles was enriched with nickel carbide particles and that the distribution of such particles was sufficiently uniform (Fig. 8(c)). A more detailed study of the chemical composition showed that the composition of the Ni1–x C x particles contained about 8 at%–10 at% carbon (Fig. 8(d)). A study of about 20 such particles showed that the carbon ratio in them is quite stable. Thus, the assumption based on the XRD data of the formation of a metastable solid solution Ni1–x C x is also confirmed by the electron microscopy data. In order to extend the results obtained for the high-loaded Ni_Alum catalysts, two other samples were treated in supercritical EtOH at 250 °C for 3 h. The first sample was prepared by coprecipitation in supercritical CO2, but Al2O3 was replaced by SiO2 [39]. The second sample, Ni/γ-Al2O3, was synthesized by the deposition-precipitation method described in one of our recent articles [15]. The XRD analysis of the reduced and EtOH-treated Ni catalysts is shown in Figs. S4 and S5. It demonstrates that both catalysts are enriched in Ni-C-containing phases such as Ni1–x C x and Ni3C, proving that the formation of these phases is typical for a wide range of nickel catalysts (Table S3). The formation of carbon deposits during the transformations of alcohols over Ni-based catalysts has been observed many times. For example, one of the early works describes the formation of dendritic structured carbon deposits from n-hexanol and cyclohexanol over metallic nickel, however, the process was carried out under hard conditions at 445–800 °C [51], so, in our study we could see the initial stages of the same process. Similar observations have been made for Ni-catalyzed ethanol steam reforming [52,53]. The authors suggest that acetaldehyde formed as a result of ethanol dehydrogenation is converted to CO, which can participate in the Boudouard reaction. Another possible mechanism for the formation of carbon deposits on the catalyst surface is the polymerization of alkenes formed from alcohol by dehydration. It is also important to note that steam reforming occurs under harsh conditions, so the formation of carbon deposits is intensified compared to the low temperature processes discussed in the current work. Based on the known data the formation of the carbide phase in interaction with primary alcohols at elevated temperatures is thought to occur by successive transformations (Fig. 9 ). In the first step, the aldehyde is formed from the alcohol by dehydrogenation (Fig. 9(1)). Next, the ketone is decarboxylated to form CO (Fig. 9(2)) [35,36], which is catalytically decomposed to carbon and CO2 (Fig. 9(3)) on the surface of metallic nickel [54]. Analysis of the gas phase after the process revealed the presence of CO and CO2 (Fig. S1). The formation of the carbide phase from the nickel phase is a stepwise process - first the enrichment of metallic nickel with carbon (Fig. 9(4)) and then the formation of the carbide phase (Fig. 9(5)) [50]. To confirm the sequence of processes (4) and (5) in the Ni3C phase formation scheme, an additional investigation was carried out to study the phase composition of the catalyst after interaction with EtOH at different temperatures. It should be noted that there is virtually no conversion of benzofuran under these conditions. Fig. 10 shows the XRD data for catalyst samples after transfer hydrogenation in EtOH medium at different temperatures. Table 4 presents data on the phase composition and structural characteristics of the crystalline phases after catalyst interaction with EtOH. In the catalyst after treatment in EtOH at a temperature of 150 °C (Fig. 10(a)), there are no phase changes compared to the catalyst before the catalytic transformations (Fig. 1). After treatment at 200 °C, the formation of a Ni1–x C x solid solution phase with an average crystallite size of 5.0 nm is observed, and a slight increase in the average size of the Ni0 crystallites from 5.0 to 7.5 nm is also observed (Fig. 10(b)). High temperature treatment at 250 °C accelerates the formation of the carbide phase and reflections of the Ni3C phase are observed (Fig. 10(c)), while the sizes of the Ni1–x C x crystallites decrease relative to the sample after treatment at 200 °C. Thus, an increase in temperature from 200 to 250 °C accelerates the formation of a more dispersed Ni1-x C x phase of the solid substitution solution, followed by the formation of a larger crystalline Ni3C phase. We believe that the absence of the TH reaction at a temperature of 150 °C is due to the strong adsorption of aldehydes on the surface of the catalyst [33], while an increase in temperature leads to structural changes in the catalyst and its irreversible deactivation. Ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) is a powerful method for obtaining information about changes in the magnetic structure of the system in situ under conditions of elevated temperature and pressure [55]. It is known that the magnetic properties of the system are very sensitive to the chemical composition and crystalline structure of the supported nanoparticles. By measuring spectral parameters such as intensity, width and shape, etc., it is possible to relate changes in the spectrum to changes in the structural and morphological properties of the system under investigation [56]. Fig. 11 shows the FMR spectra of the Ni_Alum catalyst in EtOH medium at 250 °C under supercritical conditions in the in situ regime. During the first 20 minutes of the experiment, there is no significant change in the shape of the resonance absorption line. The line shape can be simulated with a high degree of consistency using the Lorentzian line. At the 20 min mark (Fig. 11(a) (ii)) the small peak at 2200 G appears and then becomes more prominent. This peak can be attributed to the formation of highly anisotropic magnetic particles in the sample. According to the XRD and TEM results, only two magnetic substances other than Ni are present in the investigated samples–Ni3C carbide and a deficient Ni1–x C x phase. In Refs. [57,58] it is reported that Ni3C particles are non-magnetic, with very low saturation magnetization, probably due to the disordered state (small size of nanoparticles). At the same time, the authors [59] report that the Ni3C1–x deficient structure exhibits significant magnetic properties, in particular high magnetocrystalline anisotropy, compared to pure Ni. In this respect, the low signal can be attributed to the formation of highly anisotropic Ni-containing particles in the system due to the reaction between Ni and EtOH with some amount of carbon infusing the Ni structure. During the first hour of the experiment, the intensity of the low-field signal increases with time, as does the intensity of the main signal. The width of the “main” line increases slowly. After 60 min, however, a sharp increase in the linewidth of the “main” signal is observed (Fig. 11(a)-(v), Fig. 11(c)). Further reaction leads to a significant increase in the intensity of the “main” line, while the intensity of the “anisotropic” component of the spectra decreases (Fig. 11(b)), while its width remains constant. These changes can be attributed to the growth of Ni nanoparticles due to agglomeration or atomic redistribution, resulting in the formation of larger Ni0 particles, while the amount of magnetically anisotropic Ni3C1–x particles decreases. This may be due to the formation of a more ordered non-magnetic Ni3C phase. After the two hours at 250 °C, the sample was heated to 300 °C, which resulted in the complete disappearance of the anisotropic signal (Fig. S6). In order to interpret the changes in the FMR spectra, the Ni_Alum catalyst was examined by XRD after the in situ FMR study (Fig. 12 ). In this sample, the main reflections belong to the Ni3C phase (PDF no. 00-006-0697) with crystal lattice parameters a = b = 4.588(1) Å, c = 13.008(1) Å and average crystallite size of 30.0(5) nm. There is also a Ni0 phase in the sample (PDF no. 00-004-0850) with lattice parameter a = 3.528 Å and crystallite size of 23.5 nm. In this sample there is no Ni1–x C x solid solution phase in contrast to the sample after reaction at 250 °C (Fig. 10(c)). It is likely that the Ni1–x C x phase completely transforms into the Ni3C phase when the temperature is increased to 300 °C in the in situ FMR study (Fig. S6). It should be noted that after interaction with all primary alcohols, the metallic nickel phase remains in the samples, but the crystallite sizes increase (Table 4). Thus, the increase in the width of the FMR spectra in Fig. 11(c) is caused by sintering processes that lead to particle enlargement and an increase in their magnetic anisotropy. Thus, the interaction of primary alcohols with a nickel-metal catalyst at temperatures above 200 °C leads to significant changes in the composition of the catalyst. Part of the metallic nickel is converted into a metastable substitutional solid solution Ni1–x C x , which subsequently transforms into the carbide phase Ni3C. Parallel to the formation of the Ni3C phase, sintering of Ni0 metal particles also takes place, but it should be noted that the complete conversion of metallic Ni0 to Ni3C does not occur. It is likely that an increase in the size of the Ni0 crystallites slows down the formation of the metastable Ni1–x C x phase and no further transformation of the catalyst occurs. These features negatively affect the kinetics of benzofuran transformations over Ni-based catalysts, resulting in catalyst deactivation. The experimental results demonstrating the relationship between catalyst structure and its activity in unambiguously show the reasons why primary alcohols show low donor activity in TH compared to secondary alcohols. As mentioned above, different research groups have observed this difference between alcohols and explained it in terms of selective adsorption of reaction products. In our study, we have shown for the first time that the decomposition of primary alcohols plays a key role in the transformation of the catalyst, at least at high temperatures. We think that this result could be interesting and helpful from both fundamental and practical points of view. 4 Conclusions In this work, the influence of the nature of the alcohol as hydrogen donor on the activity of a metal Ni-based catalyst in the hydrogenation of benzofuran under TH conditions has been studied. It has been shown that the use of the secondary alcohol 2-PrOH as hydrogen donor allows the successful hydrogenation of benzofuran. Thus, at a temperature of 250 °C only complete dearomatization takes place and only at a temperature of 300 °C do deoxygenation processes begin. According to the XRD data, the use of 2-PrOH as hydrogen donor at temperatures between 82 and 300 °C does not lead to any significant changes in the phase composition of the catalyst or in the sizes of the metallic nickel crystallites. The use of primary alcohols such as MeOH, EtOH and 1-PrOH as hydrogen donors does not lead to any significant conversion of benzofuran under TH conditions. The experiments performed clearly showed that the low donor activity of primary alcohols compared to secondary alcohols in TH is due to significant structural changes in the catalyst that occur at a process temperature of 250 °C as a result of interaction with primary alcohols. The Ni1–x C x substitutional solid solution phase is formed and its sequential transformation to the Ni3C nickel carbide phase is observed. Segregation and enlargement of nickel metal crystallites on the surface of spherical agglomerates consisting of a stabilizing alumina matrix also occurs. It has been shown that the use of primary alcohols as hydrogen donors leads to irreversible deactivation of the Ni-containing catalyst due to sintering of the metal phase and formation of the inactive Ni3C carbide phase. coredata.dc:description: The effect of different types of alcohols used as hydrogen donors on the activity of a metal Ni-based catalyst in the hydrogenation of benzofuran as a model substrate under transfer hydrogenation conditions has been studied. The hydrogenation process of benzofuran using 2-PrOH as a hydrogen donor leads sequentially to dearomatization and then to deoxygenation of the substrates. At the same time, the use of primary alcohols such as MeOH, EtOH and 1-PrOH as hydrogen donors leads to irreversible deactivation of the Ni-containing catalyst. A clear mechanism of deactivation of Ni-based metal catalysts by primary alcohols has been established. The interaction of the catalyst with primary alcohols at a temperature of 250 °C leads to the formation of an inactive Ni3C carbide phase, as well as sintering and segregation of metal particles on the surface of the alumina support.
